Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Biological Shape Spaces, Transforming Shape into Knowledge
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: Biological Shape Spaces, Transforming Shape into Knowledge

This project will develop a framework to represent, analyze and interpret shapes extracted from images, supporting a wide range of biological investigations. The primary objectives are: (1) to develop a mathematical framework and computational tools for the quantification and analysis of shapes; (2) to integrate these computational models with machine learning and statistical inference methods to enable new discoveries, transforming imaging data into biological knowledge; (3) to deliver novel quantitative methodologies for shape analysis that start from a biological premise, rather than a purely geometric one. The aim is thus not only to quantitatively describe shape, but to develop methods for linking morphological variation to its underlying biological causes. To ensure that the project focuses on methods that are most promising to biology with significant breadth of application, model and tool development will be guided and supported by a set of diverse case studies, ranging from the sub-cellular to organismal scales.

Shape represents a complex and rich source of biological information that is fundamentally linked to underlying mechanisms and function. However, shape is still often examined on a qualitative basis in many disciplines in biology, an approach that is time consuming and prone to human subjectivity. While ad hoc quantitative methods do exist, they are often inaccessible to non-experts and do not easily generalize to a wide variety of problems. The inability of biologists to systematically link shape to genetics, development, environment, function and evolution often precludes advances in biological research spanning diverse spatial and temporal scales, from the movement of molecules within a cell to adaptive changes in organismal morphology. The primary goal of this project is to develop a new suite of widely applicable quantitative methods and tools into the study of biological shape to address the significant need for consistent and repeatable analysis of shape data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many bats species can navigate complex natural environments using
sonar as their sole means of obtaining information on the outside
world. Engineered sensing systems have yet to match these
capabilities. Complex three-dimensional shapes are key components in
the bats biosonar system: Bats with most sophisticated biosonar
systems emit their ultrasonic pulses nasally and have special
"megaphone-like" baffle structures (noseleaves) surrounding their
nostrils. Similarly, the outer ears (pinna) that bats use to receive
the echoes from their environments have special global and local shape
features. Bat noseleaves and pinna are both considerably more complex
than the shapes commonly used in engineering and hence difficult to
analyze. To understand the nature of these complicated biological
shapes, a collaborative research project has brought methods from
computer shape analysis to bear on this problem. These methods were
used to analyze the biodiversity in the noseleaf and pinna shapes
across different bat species. To this end, methods were developed to
pick up local shape features such as ridges or grooves across
different shapes automatically. The acoustic, i.e., ultrasonic,
function of the noseleaves and ears can also be expressed in a
three-dimensional shape that is called a beampattern. A beampattern
specifies the relative amplitude of the emitted ultrasonic wave or the
relative receiver sensitivity as a function of direction and
frequency. Research in the project has for the first time been able to
conduct an objective analysis of the diversity in these functional
shapes (beampattern) across a large number (slightly more than 100)
different bat species. This analysis has yielded clear trends in the
diversity of bat biosonar function that highlight the importance of
beamwidth as a function of frequency and have revealed the importance
of a center-surround antagonism in the composition of the different
beampatterns. Shape processing methods have also been used to track
and analyze dynamical changes in the shapes of the noseleaves and
pinnae of individual bats. These dynamic changes happen on very short,
i.e., subsecond, time scales and can result in large changes to the
geometry of the structure (e.g., displacement of up to 20% of the
pinna length). The shape processing methods developed have laid the
foundation for a quantitative analysis fo the impact that these fast
changes have on the encoding of sensory information. Digital shape
manipulation techniques used in project have also been applied to
bring a vampire bat skeleton on display in the "Hall of Bones" in the
Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History back to life. The
digital animation will be accessible to the museum's visitors through
an app that adds a new virtual dimension to the displays.
